awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Subglacial Antarctic Lakes Scientific Access (SALSA): Integrated Study of Carbon Cycling in Hydrologically-active Subglacial Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
The Antarctic subglacial environment remains one of the least explored regions on Earth.  This project will examine the physical and biological characteristics of Subglacial Lake Mercer, a lake that lies 1200m beneath the West Antarctic Ice Sheet.  This study will address key questions relating to the stability of the ice sheet, the subglacial hydrological system, and the deep-cold subglacial biosphere.  The education and outreach component aims to widely disseminate results to the scientific community and to the general public through short films, a blog, and a website.

Subglacial Lake Mercer is one of the larger hydrologically active lakes in the southern basin of the Whillans Ice Plain, West Antarctica.  It receives about 25 percent of its water from East Antarctica with the remainder originating from West Antarctica, is influenced by drain/fill cycles in a lake immediately upstream (Subglacial Lake Conway), and lies about 100 km upstream of the present grounding line of the Ross Ice Shelf.  This site will yield information on the history of the Whillans and Mercer Ice Streams, and on grounding line migration.  The integrated study will include direct sampling of basal ice, water, and sediment from the lake in concert with surface geophysical surveys over a three-year period to define the hydrological connectivity among lakes on the Whillans Ice Plain and their flow paths to the sea. The geophysical surveys will furnish information on subglacial hydrology, aid the site selection for hot-water drilling, and provide spatial context for interpreting findings. The hot-water-drilled boreholes will be used to collect basal ice samples, provide access for direct measurement of subglacial physical, chemical, and biological conditions in the water column and sediments, and to explore the subglacial water cavities using a remotely operated vehicle equipped with sensors, cameras, and sampling equipment. Data collected from this study will address the overarching hypothesis "Contemporary biodiversity and carbon cycling in hydrologically-active subglacial environments associated with the Mercer and Whillans ice streams are regulated by the mineralization and cycling of relict marine organic matter and through interactions among ice, rock, water, and sediments". The project will be undertaken by a collaborative team of scientists, with expertise in microbiology, biogeochemistry, hydrology, geophysics, glaciology, marine geology, paleoceanography, and science communication.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to access cleanly and sample subglacial lakes along the Siple Coast of Antarctica to study the role of relict carbon in driving subglacial microbial ecosystems. The project was descoped at funding to only access one subglacial lake, and the PIs chose Mercer Subglacial Lake at the intersection of two major ice streams (the Mercer and Whillans ice streams) as their target.  

Antarctica is covered by a thick ice sheet that has changed cyclically over geologic time. A connected system of lakes and rivers, liquid due to the pressure of the overlying ice, exists underneath this ice. The subglacial water system of Antarctica can host microbial life, transport nutrients to the sea, and preserve sedimentary records of past changed in Antarctic ice cover. For these reasons, it is important to know about these systems. Knowledge of how ice changed in the past and how this altered biologic communities beneath the ice is important to forecasting the sensitivity of Antarctic ice to current climate change.

Mercer Subglacial Lake (abbreviated SLM) was cleanly accessed below 1087 meter of ice in the Antarctic summer of 2018-2019. The scientific team determined that no microbial life had been introduced to the system due to filtration and ultraviolet light, as well as rigorous disinfection of instrumentation lowered into the lake. The lake was found to be 15 meters deep. The science team sampled the water of the lake, the material floating in the water, and the sediments below the lake. Some analyses were performed in laboratories transported to the field site, others were performed at the laboratories of the McMurdo Research Station, and some samples were shipped to universities for further analyses. Sediment samples were both sampled in the field for time-sensitive analyses and to the National Marine Geology Repository at Oregon State University.  

The team found that the lake was young (~180 years old) based on the first observation of laminated lake sediments sampled from such a lake, however the organic carbon, made from microbes and other organisms, stored in sediments was old. A significant portion of the old organic carbon, once separated, dated to the early to mid Holocene. Whereas other carbon bearing components of the lake were also old, they were not devoid of radioactive carbon-14. This means that there was transfer of the young organic carbon into the older reservoirs, such as carbon dissolved in the water of the lake. This finding was consistent with observation of metabolically active microbes. In fact, measurement of the rates which those microbes metabolized during incubation studies in the field and at McMurdo Research Station showed that the carbon-14 signatures likely occur in other parts of the interconnected water system under the Antarctic ice.

 

The implications of this project?s results are that Antarctica is a much more dynamic continent than previously known. The findings of mid-Holocene retreat and re-advance of the Siple Coast grounding line (where ice on the continent becomes ice that is floating on the sea) show that indirect feedbacks to climate change (natural or man-made) can cause significant changes to the configuration of Antarctic ice. This means that, under current climate change, non-linear and potentially incongruent responses of Antarctic ice. These findings are important to incorporate in numerical simulations that are designed to better understand ice-atmosphere-ocean interactions in the past and in the future.

 

Currently, USF has led publication of several important findings from this project. The science team published protocols and methods to allow researchers who can cross-contaminate each other?s work to work together in a borehole that was only ~60 cm (24 inches) in diameter. A rigorous testing, cleaning, and re-testing protocol had to be implemented. This protocol allowed sampling of many facets of the carbon cycle in SLM and was published in the journal Radiocarbon. Another manuscript published in the journal Geophysical Research Letters interpreted prior evidence of instability in the Holocene. USF is also leading a submitted manuscript to the journal Science (age of the lake and dominant processes) and one that is being prepared for submission to the journal Geology (accurate determination of the last marine incursion). There will be more work emanating from this successful project in the coming years.

This grant supported the training of a Ph.D. graduate (Dr. Ryan Venturelli), who is now a postdoctoral researcher at Tulane University, as well as a technician at USF who helped prepare and analyze samples comprising Dr. Venturelli?s dissertation. Dr. Venturelli is a first generation college graduate who now has extensive Antarctic field experience and invaluable laboratory experience in world-class laboratories using cutting edge techniques. Dr. Venturelli was crucial to the success of this project, both in the field (where the success of the project puts the U.S. at the forefront of Antarctic research capabilities) and in the laboratory.
